text:
Are the gains from this <#C6A044SQH|helpdesk> bot really worth it? When I expressed that I thought it was obnoxious, the reaction was essentially, "I don't give a @&$%"

Some people agreed. Some people disagreed. I know it bothers me enough that I've distanced myself from Slack because of it (and, to a certain extent, Julia generally and my evangelism for the language for that matter). 

Are the gains worth alienating people like me who may admittedly be in the minority?

elements.text: Are the gains from this

bot really worth it? When I expressed that I thought it was obnoxious, the reaction was essentially, "I don't give a @&$%"

Some people agreed. Some people disagreed. I know it bothers me enough that I've distanced myself from Slack because of it (and, to a certain extent, Julia generally and my evangelism for the language for that matter). 

Are the gains worth alienating people like me who may admittedly be in the minority?

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>

Success, it has been cross posted <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/56695| to Discourse>. Keep and eye out on Discourse for responses and please add an answer there once you are satisfied with the solution so others can benefit as well. Happy debugging!

I don't understand why you react to strongly to it. And since I find it strange, I'm inclined to believe there aren't many people like you.
Could be useful to hear from people on Discourse, though, if they have an opinion about the bot.

text: :floppy_disk:?

Possible solution 1:

Newbie asks a question. If people here see that the question would be good cross posted to Discourse they react with a :bridge: . If there are enough :bridge: s, the bot is triggered. Possible solution 2: Remove the bot.

text:
Following up on Eric’s suggestion:
>  Newbie asks a question. If people here see that the question would be good cross posted to Discourse they react with a :bridge: . If there are enough :bridge: s, the bot is triggered. If the original poster agrees by also reacting with :bridge:, then it is cross posted along with any responses also with :bridge: reactions.
Right now the author triggers the bridge. Why would we need other people to approve it? If I think my question is good and worth cross posting, I don’t really care (candidly) whether other people think it’s a good question or not, it’s my question and I want it cross posted.

The argument around the bot interaction being the newbies first experience is not something help desk nor slack specific. There are more and more bots working as the proverbial door people across many sites. It’s a normal experience in my opinion and not one that makes our slack workspace unique (Discord, Discourse, GitHub, Slack welcome messages, etc.)

s, the bot is triggered. If the original poster agrees by also reacting with
, then it is cross posted along with any responses also with
reactions.

Right now the author triggers the bridge. Why would we need other people to approve it? If I think my question is good and worth cross posting, I don’t really care (candidly) whether other people think it’s a good question or not, it’s my question and I want it cross posted.

The argument around the bot interaction being the newbies first experience is not something help desk nor slack specific. There are more and more bots working as the proverbial door people across many sites. It’s a normal experience in my opinion and not one that makes our slack workspace unique (Discord, Discourse, GitHub, Slack welcome messages, etc.)

text: Because only the initial question is automatically bridged (not any subsequent discussion), the state of the conversation isn't shared between Discourse & Slack, which adds overhead for those trying to reconstruct the conversation. I agree that it'd be better to move to a more-curated archiving strategy - the best time to archive a question is after it's resolved, and we shouldn't start from the assumption that every newbie question merits archival.

elements.text: Because only the initial question is automatically bridged (not any subsequent discussion), the state of the conversation isn't shared between Discourse & Slack, which adds overhead for those trying to reconstruct the conversation. I agree that it'd be better to move to a more-curated archiving strategy - the best time to archive a question is after it's resolved, and we shouldn't start from the assumption that every newbie question merits archival.

text:
Regarding
> But the other part is that why create this artificially higher bar for these questions.
I'd say that this is *not* an artificially higher bar, but the bridge bot has created a flood of extremely low quality, noisy content on Discourse. If *any* of these posts were created by a human, people would respond with linking to the <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/psa-make-it-easier-to-help-you/14757> post and tell them that they are not asking questions in a productive or helpful way.

elements.text: Regarding
But the other part is that why create this artificially higher bar for these questions.
I'd say that this is
not
an artificially higher bar, but the bridge bot has created a flood of extremely low quality, noisy content on Discourse. If
any
of these posts were created by a human, people would respond with linking to the
post and tell them that they are not asking questions in a productive or helpful way.

text: Speaking of which, we should probably have this conversation on discourse instead of Slack because (IMO) it's more relevant to the health of the discourse community than the Slack community and we probably don't want the points made here to disappear.
